content.rendered:
After an extremely long hiatus — thanks for your patience not just with this feature but with our irregular posting schedule over the last two months — Friday Likes is back! After yesterday’s Merck identity I feel like we all need some simplicity, almost a cleansing, which is available in this edition of Friday Likes, with work from London, Singapore, and Amberg.

Twice by SocioDesign

Twice Fashion is a Chinese fashion accessories brand based in Beijing, offering jewelry, handbags, sunglasses, and more. Designed by London-based SocioDesign the new logo is reminiscent of a wishbone and although chicken bones is not something one would associate with a fashion brand the logo is a beautiful, simple icon. Its tapering, thick-and-thin construction is what makes it work so well and pair perfectly with a matching wordmark (best appreciated at the link). The tan, salmon, and grays color palette serves as the perfect backdrop for some black foil stamping, giving everything an upscale feminine look. See full project

EDL by Bravo

Based in Singapore, EDL designs and manufactures high-end laminates for use by architects and interior designers. Designed by local firm Bravo, the logo has a very simple modular concept that hints at the modular panes of laminates offered by EDL. It’s not a groundbreaking logo but its simplicity and minimal use of elements yields an interesting wordmark that can handle any texture behind it. I particularly like the black on white application where the logo lands on top of some sexily embossed typography. See full project

ba.ro.co. by Studio Stefanowitsch

ba.ro.co, short for Bavarian Roasting Company, is a small regional manufacturer of specialty coffee in Amberg, Germany. Designed by local firm Studio Stefanowitsch, the new identity relies on three dots, that are a nod to the three coffee varieties the company started with. Their first use is to create a short version of the name, from Bavarian Roasting Company to ba.ro.co, which is a clever way of making the name shorter and, heck, cooler. Their second use is to create a shorthand for the short name, from ba.ro.co to b… It’s like a fully thought out “responsive” logo, getting shorter as space is more limited but also getting cooler as desired. The sole use of Klim Type Foundry’s Tiempos gives the whole thing a lovely, bookish yet contemporary feel, perfect for sipping coffee in a b…-branded cup. See full project
